bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to M.B. Crowell, July 14, 1923

div1.p: Carter offers suggestions for preparing abstracts for a publication and encloses an abstract written by himself.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to M.B. Crowell, July 14, 1923
div1.opener:
Miscel.
N. L. L.
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 14, 1923.
Dr. M. B. Crowell, Office Editor,
Thomas Nelson & Sons, Publishers
Nelson Loose-Leaf Medicine,
381 Fourth Avenue, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Crowell:
div1.p:
I am enclosing the Summary of Progress together with the abstracts
of articles upon yellow fever which you sent me.

1/ If, as I am quite certain, you do not wish to take up a great
deal of space in your book with yellow fever, I would suggest that in
future you make the abstracts as short as you can, as--say--Nos. 1:5:
6: 8: ? and 12, and I will write as short a summary as I can.

It is fair to say that abstracts of the class suggested give little
idea of the article and it will be necessary to read the articles in
their entirety before one can write the summary of progress, which natur-
ally throws more work on me. Still it is somewhat better than a mere
bibliography and it seems to me that abstracts as long as some of those
submitted--the one of Gouzien (7) for instance--will result in increas-
ing the space taken up by yellow fever unduly in proportion to its im-
portance to most of your readers.

2/ If practicable I would be glad if you would send me either (a)
the article by Anigstein, your abstract (1) or (b) an abstract thereof
that will give one an idea as to what he said. The journal you quote,
published in Warsaw, is not entered on the files of the Surgeon General's
office. The last number was July 1914.
